resources.string:
Limit alcohol\n
Reduce salt (sodium) in your diet\n
Regular physical activity\n
Eating a diet rich in whole grains, fruits, vegetables and low-fat dairy products and low in saturated fat and cholesterol

Heart attack or stroke

Heart failure

Kidney problems

Eye problems

Metabolic syndrome

Changes with memory or understanding

Dementia

Drinking more fluids

Getting up slowly after sitting or lying down

Not drinking alcohol

Not standing for a long time (if you have NMH)

Using compression stockings so blood does not collect in the legs

Repeated fainting spells

Coma

Stroke due to reduced blood supply to the brain

Cardiovascular diseases

Consult the doctor immediately if you keep losing weight without changing your diet or exercise routine

Use nutrition shakes to get more calories

Add flavour enchancers to your food to improve the taste so that you eat more

Refer to a dietitian for advice and counseling

Cancer

Mental health complications, such as depression, anxiety, eating disorders and obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)

Problems with digestion, such as coeliac disease or irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

Other health conditions, such as an overactive thyroid, type 2 diabetes, or heart failure
